q: What is a stye?
a: A stye is a small, painful lump on or inside the eyelid or around the eye. It may be swollen and red, and filled with yellow pus.

q: How long does a stye usually last?
a: A stye should clear up on its own within 1 or 2 weeks.

q: How can I treat a stye at home?
a: To treat a stye at home, you can soak a clean flannel in warm water and hold it against your eye for 5 to 10 minutes, repeating this 3 or 4 times a day. You can also take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen to relieve the pain.

q: Can I burst a stye or remove an eyelash myself?
a: No, you should not try to burst a stye or remove an eyelash yourself, as it can spread the infection.

q: When should I see a GP for a stye?
a: You should see a GP for a stye if it is very painful or swollen, does not get better within a few weeks, or affects your vision.

q: What can a GP do for a stye?
a: A GP may burst the stye with a thin, sterilised needle, remove the eyelash closest to the stye, or refer you to an eye specialist in the hospital.

q: What causes a stye?
a: Styes are often caused by bacteria infecting an eyelash follicle or eyelid gland. They can also be more common if you have long-term blepharitis or rosacea.

q: How can I prevent styes?
a: To help prevent styes, keep your eyes clean by washing your face and removing eye makeup before bed. Replace your eye makeup every 6 months and keep your eyelids and eyelashes clean, especially if you have blepharitis. Also, avoid sharing towels or flannels with someone who has a stye and avoid rubbing your eyes if you haven't recently washed your hands.

q: Is a stye contagious?
a: Styes are generally not contagious, but the bacteria that cause them can be spread through direct contact. It's important to practice good hygiene to prevent the spread of infection.

q: Can a stye affect both eyes?
a: A stye usually only affects one eye, but it is possible to have more than one stye at a time.

q: What are the symptoms of a stye?
a: Symptoms of a stye include a painful lump on or inside the eyelid or around the eye, swelling and redness, and the possibility of the lump being filled with yellow pus.

You can also take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen to relieve the pain. It is important to avoid wearing contact lenses and eye make-up until the stye has healed.

a: A stye should not typically affect your vision. However, if your vision is affected, it is recommended to see a GP for further evaluation.

q: Can children get styes?
a: Yes, children can also get styes. However, it is important to consult a GP for appropriate treatment if a child has a stye.
